Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Recruitment and Retention of Women of Color in Political Science to Improve Scholarship and Teaching, San Francisco, CA, September 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

Research demonstrates that women of color face barriers such as lack of mentorship, financial resources, and significant familial responsibilities in their pursuit of higher education and subsequent careers in political science. Political science is one of the most male and Anglo dominated fields of study in the social sciences. Descriptive representation within the academic profession is important to perceptions of legitimacy, service to students, and development of knowledge. The goal of the conference is to provide attendees the necessary skills and networks to enter the academy, successfully achieve tenure and sustain their careers thereafter. This workshop brings together scholars from different universities, at different stages in their careers, to deepen intellectual engagement and to build coalitions that support excellence in diversifying the political science profession.

Technical Summary

Descriptive representation within the academic profession is important to perceptions of legitimacy, service to students, and development of knowledge. The goal of the conference is to provide attendees the necessary skills and networks to enter the academy, successfully achieve tenure and sustain their careers thereafter. This workshop brings together scholars from different universities, at different stages in their careers, to deepen intellectual engagement and to build coalitions that support excellence in diversifying the political science profession. The workshop includes an opening plenary session that focuses on the development of intersectionality work in the discipline and a discussion of the discipline and the role of women of color therein. It also includes a series of breakout sessions that focus on various aspects of academic development. The workshop will facilitate deep mentoring by pairing graduate students, junior, and mid-career participants by interest, with structured one-on-one mentoring time embedded into the schedule.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Women of Color in Political Science Workshop (WCPS15) was held September 2, 2015 in San Francisco. The goal of WCPS15 was to provide attendees the necessary knowledge, skills and networks to enter the academy, successfully achieve tenure and sustain their careers thereafter. It brought together scholars from different universities, at different stages in their careers, to deepen intellectual engagement and to build coalitions that support excellence in diversifying the political science profession. WCPS15 hosted 78 women of color in political science and consisted of 12 panel sessions, a plenary, a mentoring lunch, and a keynote address.  

The 21 women faculty presenters contacted about WCPS15 almost unanimously gave their immediate and enthusiastic support. They recognized the importance and value of the networking and mentoring themes of the workshop, and helped encourage the junior women from their universities to attend. During the workshop two surveys were administered to all in attendance, and all were invited to participate in focus groups the following morning. On September 3, 2015 several focus groups were held and data was collected. 

One significant outcome of the workshop was that participants overwhelmingly reported that the workshop stimulated important dialogue surrounding critical issues related to their experience. Specifically they indicated that WCPS15 content provided strategies for success in academia. Many junior and graduate student women were able to identify both peer and senior mentors at the workshop, and received helpful advice from the administrators, panelists, and other participants. 

Several important themes for the retention of junior women faculty emerged at WCPS15. Based on our pre- and post- workshop survey results, participants learned essential skills for advancement in academia and beyond. The response category for each question included a Likert scale: 1: Not at all confident, 2: A little confident 3: Somewhat confident, 4: Fairly confident, and 5: Very confident. The survey findings in the table below demonstrate growth across all areas covered by content in the workshop, and significant (more than 1 unit increase) in seven categories including: post-tenure strategies for advancement, getting tenure, becoming an administrator, negotiating a job offer, public intellectualism, navigating the job market, and careers outside academia. WCPS15 surveys helped quantify its success.

Beyond the immediate gains WCPS15 provided in terms of skills, knowledge and networking for participants, the workshop also pushed at least two participants to seek funding and replicate what we did on their home campuses. Finally, a number of panelists and participants have written reflective articles about their experiences at WCPS15 which are being compiled for publication along with our quantitative survey and qualitative focus group data.

WCPS15 contributed to the building of supportive networks based on mentoring and good information, which can make the difference in the professional lives of women of color in political science. We are confident that the workshop made a difference to the participants as well as to the discipline overall. WCPS15 built a mentoring network of women of color in the political science discipline by addressing the challenges faced by graduate students and faculty as women of color and by building connections among the participants for the purpose of enhancing research and teaching on women of color in the discipline. The workshop included plenary and panel sessions on research related to topics on women of color such as political participation, intersectionality, public policy, and interdisciplinary, classroom and curriculum issues in courses about women of color, preparation for important professional milestones, such as going on the job market, going up for tenure and/or promotion to higher ranks in the professoriate, building a research agenda and publishing strategies, and acknowledgment of departmental climate issues faced by researchers in this area. Participants chose among small group discussion sessions on different theories, methods (quantitative and qualitative approaches), frameworks, and empirical topics commonly encountered in research on women of color.

Social media and email list-servs were used to publicize the workshop (see https://www.facebook.com/WCPS15/). The Facebook page has since been utilized to disseminate research and newsworthy articles about women/women of color in academia, policy concerns and higher education issues. The Facebook page now reaches approximately 900 people.

Our recommendation, based on strong support from participants, is to hold a similar workshop every two years.
